awd_titl_txt: Mentoring to Accelerate Retention and Change Outcomes in Science (MARCOS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mentoring to Accelerate Retention and Change Outcomes in Science (MARCOS) Scholar Program is a National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Nevada State College. The project is designed to recruit and guide talented low-income students from local high schools through college graduation and graduate school enrollment in biology-related fields or employment in the workforce. The project will recruit and enroll at least 16 talented, low-income students in biology concentrations, supporting them with financial aid, faculty mentoring, blocked classes, graduate school preparation, and other programs. The program aims to meet at least 60 percent of the unmet need of the SSTEM scholars. This is based on analysis of data indicating that students with greater than 60 percent unmet need have notable lower retention rates. The project aims to encourage these talented biology students to consider pursuing advanced degrees in biology-related fields. Encouraging low-income talented students to obtain advanced degrees in scientific fields will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well-being of the nation.

The MARCOS Scholar program will study factors that contribute to students' understanding of graduate school admissions criteria.  Pilot data shows that first-generation, low-income students have inaccurate views regarding criteria for graduate admission. The project will evaluate which activities increase the entry of biology students into graduate programs. Research will focus on the impact of social belonging, research opportunities, course assistantships and graduate preparation experiences. The project will develop and articulate a replicable model to encourage talented low-income students to consider graduate training in STEM, relying on low-cost approaches. Efforts include financial support based on an institutional data-driven unmet need threshold that correlates with strong retention; incrementally increasing financial support each year to incent retention and completion; and integration of other paid employment opportunities that are known to benefit students academically, such as summer research positions, summer internships, and course assistantships. These methods will collectively result in a program that serves more students with less funding, maximizing the breadth of impact of support. Creating pathway programs that guide low-income students from high school toward graduate-level success is critical from an educational standpoint, and doing so in STEM fields is of critical importance for the nation's economic competitiveness in advanced technologies. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the science education community.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: NSHE Board of Regents on behalf of Nevada State College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Award Title: Mentoring to Accelerate Retention and Change Outcomes in Science (MARCOS)
Federal Award ID: 1643777
Report Submission Period: 06/01/2023 to 05/31/2024

 Mentoring to Accelerate Retention and Change Outcomes in Science (MARCOS)

NSF S-STEM OUTCOMES REPORT

Nevada State University

The Mentoring to Accelerate Retention and Change Outcomes in Science (MARCOS) Scholar Program was funded by the National Science Foundation to recruit and enroll at least 16 talented, low-income high school students in Biology concentrations, supporting them with scholarship, faculty mentoring, course scheduling, graduate school preparation, and research and internship experiences. The MARCOS program provided scholarships to 49 Biology students more than tripling the goal in the original proposal. Of the 27 MARCOS Scholars who have already graduated, 56.6% identified as Hispanic, 7.4% as African American or Black, 14.8% as Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, and 22.2% as White females resulting in a substantial increase in the diversity of STEM-trained individuals entering the workforce.

The success of the MARCOS Scholar Program is evident by increasing retention which is the number of first-time freshman semester who enter in the fall semester return to school in the spring. There were 91.8% of MARCOS Scholars retained compared to 82.8% for students who did not receive these services. The National Center for Education Statistics reports that only 64% of students graduate from bachelor's degree programs within 6-years. Impressively the MARCOS Scholars achieved a 73% graduation rate in only 4 years compared to 23.3% for other low income, high achieving Biology students at Nevada State University. The MARCOS Scholar Program connects students with critical hands-on training through internships and research. As a result, 92.1% of MARCOS Scholars have completed intensive research experiences, and 40% of those wrote Undergraduate Research Opportunity grants to provide additional scholarships ranging from $3,000 - $7,500 offsetting the cost of attending college. Nearly 38% of the MARCOS Scholar graduates have already entered the STEM workforce or graduate school.

Students in the MARCOS Scholar Program received dedicated faculty support, blocked scheduling of classes, access to tutors, and extensive professional development to prepare them for future careers in STEM. Further, the MARCOS Scholar Program went beyond scholastic support to provide critical mentorship in order to break down barriers in order for students to be their authentic selves and feel accepted. As a result of these efforts, MARCOS Scholars report improved feelings of belonging, and ability to succeed in STEM. Of interest, students who reported higher non-academic interactions like personal mentorship, financial counseling, socialization, and emotional support from faculty had higher levels of feeling they can succeed in science. This data suggests that an integrated approach to mentorship is more beneficial than one that is strictly academic.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Samantha Jewell
